awd_titl_txt: SBE: Small: Continuous Human-User Authentication by Induced Procedural Visual-Motor Biometrics
awd_abstract_narration:
Validating a user's identity is one of the fundamental security requirements in cyberspace. Current authentication approaches require people to create and remember secret credentials such as complex passwords, or to possess special hardware authentication tokens. Both are vulnerable to being compromised, or illegally shared. Even worse, authentication is typically supported solely at the start of a session. Recent developments in biometric authentication aim to overcome these challenges, but are either easy to bypass (e.g., imposter attacks), incapable of satisfactory false-positive-false-negative tradeoffs, or require expensive dedicated equipment. To address these weaknesses, the objective of this project is to develop a non-traditional approach to biometric authentication, which exploits motor learning and visual-motor adaptation to provide secure, effective and continuous human-user authentication.

This project focuses on developing a new paradigm in cyber security - expertise-based continuous biometric authentication. The uniqueness of the new paradigm is to actively train the subject to achieve continuous authentication, by inducing a specific expertise into a human subject's interaction with a machine. An expertise is defined as an artificially-induced interaction pattern that is unique to the human subject. Once the subjects have been exposed to specific stimuli and learned their expertise, their behaviors are easily differentiable as long as the stimuli are maintained. To enhance the security of the system, as well as to preserve user privacy (by facilitating expertise fade-out after the cessation of the stimuli), the induced expertise are not static, but rather continuously evolving between randomly-chosen targets. The project develops expertise-based active biometric authentication modalities based on keyboard, mouse, and touchscreen devices. The outcome of this research shall have broader impacts on the nation's higher education, high-tech industries, and government. The research enhances the PIs' curriculum developments and helps attract, recruit and retain engineering students and broaden the participation of under-represented minorities and women in engineering programs. It also supports the PIs to outreach to talented college and high-school students and motivate them to study and eventually pursue Doctoral degrees in computer engineering areas.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits: Currently, mainstream biometric user authentication approaches are based on passive measurements of the human subject’s characteristics and often come with less-than-satisfactory accuracy. Our study takes a unique approach to biometric authentication. Specifically, instead of training a machine learning algorithm to recognize a legitimate user, our research aims to design and evaluate a hybrid type of training in which a legitimate user is trained to use a customized instance of the machine. The user thus achieves a level of artificially induced expertise to interact with the machine, which makes the user easier to recognize.

 

We have implemented this concept in a mouse-based user authentication system, in which we produce customized machine instances by introducing an angle offset to the standard mouse. Human subjects then rely on their kinesthetic intelligence to achieve motor learning and visual-motor adaptation to the modified mouse. We designed a 7-week IRB-approved experiment, collected data from 18 human subjects over this period, and evaluated the proposed approach with two existing state-of-the-art mouse-based authentication schemes. We find that, in both schemes, our approach significantly outperforms the baseline in which a regular unaltered mouse is used. Surprisingly, results have shown that our approach improves the authentication performance even when both legitimate and non-legitimate users are trained to exactly the same instance of the customized machine (i.e., the same mouse angle offset).

 

With this new approach (combining Artificial and Kinesthetic Intelligence), unique interaction patterns between humans and machines can make the user easier to recognize. Our results showed that this holds even when the legitimate and non-legitimate users are trained to the same exact instance of the machine. We also observed that most human users (at different ages) can generally maintain their learned expertise in operating with the angle-biased mouse even after one week of washout, which further demonstrated the practicality of the systems employing such a new approach.

 

Finally, we study and present practical strategies to help manage the enrollment of users in such a proposed AI-KI authentication system and investigate other factors that impact the practicality of this new user authentication paradigm in real-world settings.

 

Broader impacts: We have trained Ph.D./MS and undergraduate REU students from the Computer Engineering and Kinesiology programs at Iowa State University. Research outcomes have been integrated into the course modules. All the human subject data were collected under the approved IRB at Iowa State University. A subset of code implementations are available on GitHub/GitLab. We have recruited female and minority students for the project.

 



Last Modified: 02/19/2024
Modified by: Yong Guan

por.por_txt_cntn:
Intellectual Merits: Currently, mainstream biometric user authentication approaches are based on passive measurements of the human subjects characteristics and often come with less-than-satisfactory accuracy. Our study takes a unique approach to biometric authentication. Specifically, instead of training a machine learning algorithm to recognize a legitimate user, our research aims to design and evaluate a hybrid type of training in which a legitimate user is trained to use a customized instance of the machine. The user thus achieves a level of artificially induced expertise to interact with the machine, which makes the user easier to recognize.





We have implemented this concept in a mouse-based user authentication system, in which we produce customized machine instances by introducing an angle offset to the standard mouse. Human subjects then rely on their kinesthetic intelligence to achieve motor learning and visual-motor adaptation to the modified mouse. We designed a 7-week IRB-approved experiment, collected data from 18 human subjects over this period, and evaluated the proposed approach with two existing state-of-the-art mouse-based authentication schemes. We find that, in both schemes, our approach significantly outperforms the baseline in which a regular unaltered mouse is used. Surprisingly, results have shown that our approach improves the authentication performance even when both legitimate and non-legitimate users are trained to exactly the same instance of the customized machine (i.e., the same mouse angle offset).





With this new approach (combining Artificial and Kinesthetic Intelligence), unique interaction patterns between humans and machines can make the user easier to recognize. Our results showed that this holds even when the legitimate and non-legitimate users are trained to the same exact instance of the machine. We also observed that most human users (at different ages) can generally maintain their learned expertise in operating with the angle-biased mouse even after one week of washout, which further demonstrated the practicality of the systems employing such a new approach.





Finally, we study and present practical strategies to help manage the enrollment of users in such a proposed AI-KI authentication system and investigate other factors that impact the practicality of this new user authentication paradigm in real-world settings.





Broader impacts: We have trained Ph.D./MS and undergraduate REU students from the Computer Engineering and Kinesiology programs at Iowa State University. Research outcomes have been integrated into the course modules. All the human subject data were collected under the approved IRB at Iowa State University. A subset of code implementations are available on GitHub/GitLab. We have recruited female and minority students for the project.
